article.title: Amphisbaena
article.paragraph: Image:Uroboros.pngthumbright200pxAmphisbaenaTheamphisbaena(IPAc-enˌæmfɪsˈbiːnə, plural:amphisbaenae) is amythological,ant-eatingSerpent (symbolism)serpentwith a head at each end. The creature is alternately called theamphisbaina,amphisbene,amphisboena,amphisbona,amphista,amfivena,amphivena, oranphivena(the last two being feminine), and is also known as the "Mother of Ants".citation needed (lead)January 2014Its name comes from theGreek languageGreekwordsamphis, meaning "both ways", andbainein, meaning "to go".citation needed (lead)January 2014According toGreek mythology, the amphisbaena was spawned from the blood that dripped from theGorgonMedusa's head asPerseusflew over theLibyan Desertwith it in his hand, after whichCato the YoungerCato's army then encountered it along with other serpents on the march.When Cato the Youngers army marched through LibyaAmphisbaenae fed off of the corpses left behind. The amphisbaena has been referred to by variouspoetssuch asNicander,John Milton,Alexander Pope,Percy Bysshe Shelley,Alfred TennysonAlfred, Lord Tennyson, andA. E. Housman;as a mythological and legendary creature, it has been referenced byLucan (poet)Lucan,Pliny the Elder,Isidore of Seville, andThomas Browne, the last of whom debunked its existence.citation needed (lead)January 2014
article.heading: Appearance
article.paragraph: quoteThe amphisbaena has a twin head, that is one at the tail end as well, as though it were not enough for poison to be poured out of one mouth.[[Pliny the Elder]]''[[Naturalis Historia]]''This early description of the amphisbaena depicts a venomous, dual-headed snakelike creature. However,Medievaland later drawings often show it with two or more scaled feet, particularly chicken feet, and feathered wings.citation neededJanuary 2015SomeWhoJanuary 2015even depict it as a horned, dragon-like creature with a serpent-headed tail and small, round ears, while others have both "necks" of equal size so that it cannot be determined which is the rear head.citation neededJanuary 2015Many descriptions of the amphisbaena say its eyes glow like candles or lightning, but the poetNicanderseems to contradict this by describing it as "always dull of eye". He also says: "From either end protrudes a blunt chin; each is far from each other."Nicander's account seems to be referring to what is indeed called theAmphisbaenia.citation neededJanuary 2015
article.heading: Habitat
article.paragraph: The amphisbaena is said to make its home in thedesert.citation neededJanuary 2015
article.heading: Folk medicine
article.paragraph: In ancient times, the supposedly dangerous amphisbaena had many uses in the art offolk medicineand other such remedies. It was saidBy whomJanuary 2015that expecting women wearing a live amphisbaena around their necks would have safe pregnancies; however, if one's goal was to cure ailments such asarthritisor thecommon cold, one should wear only its skin.citation neededJanuary 2015By eating the meat of the amphisbaena, one could supposedly attract many lovers of the opposite sex, and slaying one during thefull mooncould give power to one who is pure of heart and mind.citation neededJanuary 2015Lumberjackssuffering from cold weather on the job could nail its carcass or skin to a tree to keep warm, while in the process allowing the tree to be felled more easily.citation neededJanuary 2015
article.heading: Origins
article.paragraph: InThe Book of Beasts,T.H. Whitesuggests that the creature derives from sightings of theAmphisbaeniaworm lizardsof the same name.The Book of BeastsThese creatures are found in the Mediterranean countries where many of these legends originated.
